Message.Title: Medical giant Stryker cuts 1170 jobs, citing Obamacare
Message.Msg: Yahoo news asked what obamacare means to you, well now we know. Over 35,000 layoffs have been announced nationwide in just 10 days following the election results. Obamacare has everything to do with government control and nothing to do with improving healthcare. Investors bought into Yahoo thinking it was going to make money with internet services, but instead yahoo using the money to fund their leftist news propaganda machine.

Message.Title: What happens when YHOO pays a big cash dividend?
Message.Msg: I see that many posters are very interested to see YHOO to pay a one time dividend but I believe they don't see what will happen if YHOO does that. Here is my strong belief on what would happen based on market facts and experiences: Facts are: 1- YHOO will lose its cash and will not have to buy back the shares and will not have money for possible acuquistions. 2- Market usually seels big cash dividend as company having no plan for growth and its cash 3- After the dividend is paid, the stock price drops at least to the amount of the dividend paid and 95% it drops much more than the dividend so you as an investor lose . Here are what happens to the investor who receives the dividend: 1- He should pay the dividend tax which is 15% in 2012 and is expected to go up to an unknown amount in 2013. 2- You cannot combine your dividend received with your loss in the market so from IRA eyes your account shows a profit which you did not. Say you have lost $5000 YTD in your trades and you get dividend, you still have to pay the dividend tax and cannot claim it towards your loss. 2- Dividend is like your bank buys you a gift with your own money and deduct the gift amount from your account. That is why many big investors short the shares just before the stock going ex-dividend because they know the shares will drop more after ex-dividend date. 3-Even paying a regular small amount of dividend, does not help the stocks and pushes them from growth sector to value sector so you don't usually see big price change in them. AAPL may not be a good example but check out and see dividend did not help AAPL from falling. So as a stock holder you should pray not to get a big one time dividend.

Message.Title: MarketGrader data from Barron's online
Message.Msg: Yahoo!, Inc. (YHOO) INTERNET SOFTWARE/SERVICES Company Scores Very Good Fundamental Grades - MarketGrader currently has a BUY rating on Yahoo!, Inc. (YHOO), based on a final overall grade of 70.4 scored by the company's fundamental analysis. Yahoo!, Inc. scores at the 95th percentile among all 5996 North American equities currently followed by MarketGrader. Our present rating dates to October 24, 2012, when it was upgraded from a HOLD. Relative to the Internet Software/Services sub-industry, which is comprised of 132 companies, Yahoo!, Inc.'s grade of 70.4 ranks 13th. The industry grade leader is Baidu, Inc. (BIDU) with an overall grade of 84.8. The stock, up 16.07% in the last six months, has outperformed both the Internet Software/Services group, down 2.78% and the S&P 500 Index, which has returned 6.53% in the same period.

Message.Title: Facebook and Yahoo! are in talks....
Message.Msg: ....about forging an alliance that could spell the end of Yahoo!’s relationship with Microsoft. Sources have told The Sunday Telegraph that Marissa Mayer, chief executive of Yahoo!, has held discussions with Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, about how the two companies can work more closely together. The two internet giants have already collaborated together on a number of small projects, for example to share Yahoo! news on Facebook, and recently agreed to settle a number of long-standing lawsuits over patents. However, board members expect the talks to lead to much more substantial collaboration based around web-based search. Facebook has already said it plans to boost its web search facility, with founder Mark Zuckerberg noting that the social network is “pretty uniquely positioned to answer the questions people have”. Forging an alliance with Yahoo! would allow the social network to take a major leap forward in search, ensuring it remains central to its users’ lives and helping to target advertising more efficiently. Meanwhile, Yahoo!, which started life as one the first major search engines but is now dwarfed by rival Google, would benefit from Facebook’s vast army of more than 1bn users.

Topic.Title: Facebook and Yahoo! are in talks....

Message.Msg: An alliance between Facebook and Yahoo! will pose a major threat to Google and stands to reorder the hierarchy of the world’s biggest technology companies. Silicon Valley observers had speculated that Ms Mayer could throw Yahoo!’s lot in with Google, her former employer, but instead she and Ms Sandberg, who is also a former Google executive, are expected to use their combined might to launch a serious competitor.

Message.Title: A Yahoo-Facebook Search Engine Would Be A Brilliant Move For Both Companies--Here's Why
Message.Msg: The Telegraph reports that Yahoo and Facebook are talking about teaming up on their own search engine. Good! This would be a smart strategic move for both companies. It could also drive billions of dollars to both companies' bottom lines. And it would finally allow the world to create a strong No. 2 to the Google search juggernaut, which would be excellent for consumers, marketers, and third-party distribution partners alike. (If Facebook and Yahoo don't actually want to build their own search engine, they could also just switch to Google for monetization. This, too, would radically increase their bottom lines.) We'll run through some numbers below. But first, here are some broad strokes: Read more at SAI
